author: By John Koblin and Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Trump’s Push to Undo Election Result Divides His Media Allies
description: The hosts of “Fox & Friends” warn of “anarchy” and say they have not seen evidence of fraud, while a Fox News colleague, Mark Levin, says the Constitution is being “destroyed” by Democrats and the media.
content: The final stretch of President Trump’s term kicked off on Monday with the Republican Party in disarray — and the president’s media allies similarly divided over how to handle the crisis brought on by his fantasies of a “rigged” election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerald Walker
title: Kiese Laymon Revisits Some Early Essays, and Reclaims His Voice
description: A contentious publishing experience left Laymon unsatisfied with his 2013 collection, “How to Slowly Kill Yourself and Others in America.” Now he’s back with Take 2.
content: HOW TO SLOWLY KILL YOURSELF AND OTHERS IN AMERICABy Kiese Laymon
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins and Troy Closson
title: Man With Extremist Right-Wing Views Is Sought in Bomb Hoax
description: The man, 22, was under scrutiny after what looked like a bomb was found on the trunk of a Tesla at a Queens mall, law enforcement officials said.
content: The 911 call came in to the police around 7:30 a.m. on Monday: A car was stopped in the middle of the circular ramp at the Queens Place Mall parking garage, leaking fumes. A fuel canister with wires attached was sitting on the car’s trunk.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Post-Covid offices could be more dynamic than ever.
description: Coronavirus will not kill the office, Dror Poleg writes for The Upshot.
content: Coronavirus will not kill the office, Dror Poleg writes for The Upshot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Playboi Carti’s Quiet Christmas Release Is His First No. 1
description: The rapper’s “Whole Lotta Red” was largely unreviewed by the music press (though it led to a Twitter hubbub), and was streamed 126 million times in its opening week.
content: You could be forgiven if you didn’t know about “Whole Lotta Red.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: As Birthrate Falls, South Korea’s Population Declines, Posing Threat to Economy
description: For the first time on record, the number of newborns in South Korea last year fell below the number of deaths, underscoring a long-term crisis in one of world’s most important economies.
content: Think of major threats to South Korea, and its nuclear-armed neighbor North Korea may come to mind. But a subtler risk to South Korea’s future well-being lies within its borders: a shrinking and rapidly aging population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Trump Campaign Settles With Artist Who Said He Was Assaulted
description: Rod Webber, a Boston artist with a provocative streak, is to receive $20,000 from the campaign, which admitted no wrongdoing.
content: President Trump’s campaign has settled a lawsuit filed by a Boston artist and documentary filmmaker who said he was assaulted by a staff member at an event in New Hampshire in 2015.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien and Kaly Soto
title: Scotland goes back into lockdown as the new variant of the virus gains a foothold.
description: Citing a steep increase in coronavirus cases and pressure on the National Health Service, Scotland’s first minister, Nicola Sturgeon, announced a new lockdown on Monday that will last until at least the end of January.
content: Citing a steep increase in coronavirus cases and pressure on the National Health Service, Scotland’s first minister, Nicola Sturgeon, announced a new lockdown on Monday that will last until at least the end of January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: The College Football Champion Not in the Title Game
description: The University of Connecticut led the way in shutting down its program in deference to coronavirus precautions. Most of the Huskies’ peers lacked the courage to do the same.
content: Who will be college football’s next national champion, Alabama or Ohio State? The correct answer should be neither.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: A Plan Made to Shield Big Tobacco From Facts Is Now E.P.A. Policy
description: The E.P.A. has finalized a so-called transparency plan that it says will improve the credibility of science. Scientists say it is designed to stop new public health protections by limiting what research the agency can consider.
content: WASHINGTON — Nearly a quarter century ago, a team of tobacco industry consultants outlined a plan to create “explicit procedural hurdles” for the Environmental Protection Agency to clear before it could use science to address the health impacts of smoking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Hundreds of Google Employees Unionize, Culminating Years of Activism
description: The creation of the union, a rarity in Silicon Valley, follows years of increasing outspokenness by Google workers. Executives have struggled to handle the change.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — More than 400 Google engineers and other workers have formed a union, the group revealed on Monday, capping years of growing activism at one of the world’s largest companies and presenting a rare beachhead for labor organizers in staunchly anti-union Silicon Valley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Spiral’ Review: A Peerless Policier Takes On Its Final Case
description: France’s answer to “The Wire” and “Law & Order” begins its final season on MHz Choice.
content: The long-running crime drama “Spiral” — its title in France, where it premiered on Canal+ back in 2005, is “Engrenages,” or “Gears” — does not take place in a postcard Paris. Tourist landmarks and picturesque boulevards are scant; the Eiffel Tower occasionally appears in the hazy distance, like a mirage. The show’s eighth and final season begins with a shot of Sacré-Coeur, but the camera pans down to the working-class Barbès district, where the dead body of a homeless Moroccan teenager is found inside a launderette washing machine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henrik Pryser Libell and Isabella Kwai
title: Rescuers Search for Survivors in Norway Landslide That Killed at Least 7
description: Seven bodies have been recovered following the disaster last week in a village north of Oslo. Three people are still missing.
content: Rescuers have recovered the bodies of seven people killed in a landslide in Norway last week, and they are still looking for survivors, the police said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bianca Giaever
title: Thinking About Growing a Beard in 2021?
description: Jeff’s Beard Board, a 20-year-old forum for facial hair, may be a useful resource.
content: Andrew Peterka had given up hope that he could ever grow serious facial hair. “My beard history has been … a bare parking lot of hair growth,” Mr. Peterka, 41, said. “I am other people’s patches. I’m the negative space of real men.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: Trump Call to Georgia Official Might Violate State and Federal Law
description: The president’s demand for action to overturn the result of the election in the state raised questions about whether he violated election fraud statutes, lawyers said, though a charge is unlikely.
content: The call by President Trump on Saturday to Georgia’s secretary of state raised the prospect that Mr. Trump may have violated laws that prohibit interference in federal or state elections, but lawyers said on Sunday that it would be difficult to pursue such a charge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Meet the Puzzle Makers of New York Times Games
description: Noca Wu makes puzzles for Vertex.
content: In Brooklyn, N.Y., in a west-facing apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: sang-froid
description: This word has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: I.R.S. Says Prince’s Estate Worth Twice What Administrators Reported
description: The federal government is seeking nearly $39 million in taxes and fees based on a valuation of Prince’s assets that his estate disputes.
content: For almost five years, the estate of Prince has been one of the music industry’s most drawn-out and complex legal thickets, as the star’s heirs aligned in two factions and business conflicts developed over Prince’s storied “vault” of unreleased music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The Heisman Trophy Goes Virtual, With a Surprise Favorite
description: Quarterbacks have claimed the award 17 times in the past 20 years. That may not happen on Tuesday night.
content: The Heisman Trophy will be handed out Tuesday night, a month later than usual in a college football season in which almost nothing has turned out quite as expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Listen to Rudolph: A New Year Is Both a Comfort and a Fiction
description: A 1976 TV movie that imagined years as people is a helpful reminder that a new page on the calendar is an arbitrary creation.
content: If 2020 were a person, what would it look like? I imagine someone tired, ravaged, beaten down by illness and police brutality, and weary from trying to stay afloat in a sinking economy. We’ve personified 2020 in articles and memes and GIFs, speaking of it as though it were a living, breathing antagonist in our collective story. And this past New Year’s celebration was not so much about the birth of a new year as about the death of an old one that no one asked for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: N.F.L. Firings: Jaguars’ Marrone and Chargers’ Lynn Are Out
description: Black Monday was not quite as dark as usual this year, with only three coaches fired after the end of the regular season.
content: Black Monday, the day when N.F.L. head coaches are often shown the door, wasn’t as dark this year. But that was only because so many coaches had already been fired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Virus Is Still Winning
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: This simple chart shows why the new variants of the coronavirus — first detected in Britain and South Africa — are so worrisome:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: Co-Living in a Brooklyn Townhouse
description: A two-room suite in a Park Slope brownstone provides a nice middle ground between living with roommates and all alone.
content: Living alone is, for many, a brass ring of adulthood. But one that, in a city as expensive as New York, can be hard to reach, as Jackson Chiappinelli, 26, discovered when he went looking for a solo living situation several years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: The Cut Finds Its New Top Editor at Teen Vogue
description: Lindsay Peoples Wagner will leave her job as the editorial leader of the Condé Nast publication to take over New York Magazine’s style and culture site.
content: The Cut, the New York Magazine style and culture website with a devoted following, named Lindsay Peoples Wagner as its new editor in chief on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Once a Foe of Trump, Cruz Leads a Charge to Reverse His Election Loss
description: The Texas Republican was once the victim of President Trump’s false claims of election fraud. Now he is perpetuating them.
content: WASHINGTON — When Donald J. Trump lost the 2016 Iowa caucuses to Senator Ted Cruz, during a campaign in which he insulted Mr. Cruz’s wife and father, the future president did what he typically does after a loss: Mr. Trump falsely claimed he had won and accused his opponent of election fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Stephen Curry Answers His Critics With a 62-Point Game
description: A career-best performance against Portland reminded the league what the Golden State Warriors guard can do.
content: Stephen Curry has heard the criticism. He is aware his legacy is being questioned, and he knows that any bad game will start again the reconsideration of his accomplishments. But after scoring a career-high 62 points for the Golden State Warriors in a 137-122 win over the Portland Trail Blazers on Sunday night, Curry sent a clear message to his critics: Keep talking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Time to Get Cooking
description: It’s go time for 2021. Buckle down and eat well, whether it’s with a spicy slow-roasted salmon or a risotto with peas and sausage.
content: Good morning. Welcome back. It’s been two weeks of people pushing off meetings and decisions, treading water in the corporate pool and the raging river of unemployment alike, nothing getting done although there’s so much to do. Today marks the end of all that. It’s go time for 2021. Time to get serious. Time to buckle down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Senator Kelly Loeffler of Georgia says she will join the vote to overturn Biden’s electors.
description: A day before facing voters in a runoff Senate election, Senator Kelly Loeffler of Georgia announced plans to vote against the Electoral College certification process, joining a dozen Republican senators in voting to overturn electors for President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.
content: A day before facing voters in a runoff Senate election, Senator Kelly Loeffler of Georgia announced plans to vote against the Electoral College certification process, joining a dozen Republican senators in voting to overturn electors for President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Without Tourism, Life in a Tuscan Village Slides Back in Time
description: The sharp drop in visitors since the start of the pandemic pressed this small community in the hills of Chianti to cling to the essentials: the pharmacy, the food store and agriculture.
content: CASTELLINA IN CHIANTI, Italy — For decades, the rolling hills of Chianti in Tuscany have been a holiday destination for tourists from all over the world. Nearly year round, visitors take on the region’s winding roads in their rental cars, admiring the landscape laboriously sculpted by farmers, where vineyards blend into olive groves, and forests of oak trees give way to cypress-lined drives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: In Georgia, Pro Teams Dive Into Senate Races With Different Playbooks
description: The W.N.B.A.’s Atlanta Dream backed a candidate for the Senate running directly against a co-owner of the team; the N.F.L.’s Atlanta Falcons promoted voter participation in general.
content: Georgia’s runoff election on Tuesday will have dramatic consequences, deciding whether Republicans or Democrats control the Senate. In an environment of heightened civic engagement for athletes, two of Atlanta’s pro teams have been rallying voters there in starkly different ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: A Kitchen Resolution Worth Making: Follow the Recipe Exactly
description: Home cooks often tweak dishes, but hewing tightly to instructions can help us better understand others and their cuisines and cultures.
content: Most nights, I throw together dinner using whatever is in my fridge, picking dishes from a mental catalog of options and preparing them from muscle memory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Biden Plans Minimalist Trip From Capitol to White House on Inauguration Day
description: Joe Biden’s inaugural committee suggested the traditional crowd-lined ride down Pennsylvania Avenue would be replaced by a “virtual parade.”
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s inaugural committee released new details on Sunday about his trip to the White House after his swearing-in at the U.S. Capitol that further underscore the downsized and largely virtual nature of his Inauguration Day plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley, Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: New Variant Detected in New York Amid Growing Crisis Over Vaccine Rollout
description: The sluggish pace of vaccinations has been particularly striking in New York City, the onetime epicenter of the pandemic.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — New York, the onetime center of the pandemic, faced a growing crisis on Monday over the lagging pace of coronavirus vaccinations, as deaths continue to rise in the second wave and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo came under mounting pressure to overhaul the process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zengerle
title: John Thompson Was More — Much More — Than a Basketball Coach
description: In his autobiography, “I Came as a Shadow,” Thompson recalls his childhood in segregated Washington, D.C., and his decades as both an athletic and a cultural force.
content: I CAME AS A SHADOW An AutobiographyBy John Thompson with Jesse Washington
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Britain, Trump, Covid-19: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: As the Georgia Runoffs Arrive, a New Book Says the Senate Is Broken
description: In “Kill Switch,” Adam Jentleson explains how the Senate has become a place where ambitious legislation goes to die.
content: According to lore, George Washington came up with the metaphor of the Senate as a “cooling saucer,” tempering the House’s blazing hot cup of tea. It’s an apocryphal story, but an evocative one nonetheless, casting the Senate as a fail-safe institution whose work is invariably carried out with wisdom and patience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu and Rebecca Robbins
title: In Europe, more countries delay second vaccine doses or mull plans to do so.
description: As governments around the world rush to vaccinate their citizens, scientists and policymakers are debating whether to reserve the second doses everyone will need, or give as many people as possible just one shot now — potentially at the expense of giving second doses on schedule.
content: As governments around the world rush to vaccinate their citizens, scientists and policymakers are debating whether to reserve the second doses everyone will need, or give as many people as possible just one shot now — potentially at the expense of giving second doses on schedule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.6 Million Homes in California
description: A modernist hillside retreat in Topanga, a French country-style home in Santa Barbara and a renovated 1929 house in Pacific Grove.
content: This house was designed to bring the rugged canyon landscape of Topanga indoors, with floor-to-ceiling windows in nearly every room. The seller, who bought it in 2018, gave it a makeover inspired by the Northern California community of Sea Ranch, cladding the exterior in naturally fire-resistant Kayu wood and adding radiata-pine floors to the interior spaces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden Plans Renewed Nuclear Talks With Russia While Punishing Kremlin, Adviser Says
description: The president-elect also plans to pursue a “follow-on negotiation” with Iran over its missile capabilities if Tehran re-enters compliance with the nuclear deal.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s incoming national security adviser said on Sunday that the new administration would move quickly to renew the last remaining major nuclear arms treaty with Russia, even while seeking to make President Vladimir V. Putin pay for what appeared to be the largest-ever hacking of United States government networks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Roston
title: Missions to Mars, the Moon and Beyond Await Earth in 2021
description: Here’s a preview of what to expect in space and astronomy in the year to come.
content: About a month after the new year has started on Earth, three spacecraft will pull into the vicinity of Mars. These explorers, which launched in July last year, will be heralds of a busy year of space exploration, launches and astronomical occurrences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dror Poleg
title: The Future of Offices When Workers Have a Choice
description: Some work spaces in central employment districts may become housing, and some housing in residential areas may become work spaces.
content: Coronavirus will not kill the office. If anything, it figures to be more dynamic than ever. The ability to work remotely will not drive most people away from cities and offices, but it will enable many to live and work in new ways and places — while causing its fair share of disruption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Iran Increases Uranium Enrichment at Key Nuclear Facility
description: The move is another a series of escalations with the United States. In another provocation, the country seized a South Korean chemical tanker.
content: Iran announced on Monday that it had increased its uranium enrichment levels, bringing it closer to developing the capacity to produce a nuclear weapon within six months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry and Sarah Hughes
title: Georgia, Vaccine, U.K. Lockdown: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Michael Crowley
title: Saudi Arabia Will Reopen Borders With Qatar, Easing a Regional Rift
description: An American official said the agreement was a prelude to a broader agreement to end a boycott of Qatar by its Gulf neighbors that has lasted for more than three years.
content: CAIRO — After a rift that has fractured the Arab world and tested American diplomacy for more than three years, Saudi Arabia agreed to reopen its borders and airspace to Qatar on Monday night after boycotting it since 2017, Kuwaiti, Qatari and American officials said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Megan Specia
title: U.K. Judge Blocks Assange’s Extradition to U.S., Citing Mental Health
description: U.S. officials want the WikiLeaks founder to face charges of violating the Espionage Act. But a judge in London ruled that he was at extreme risk of suicide.
content: LONDON — A British judge ruled on Monday that the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange cannot be extradited to the United States to face trial on charges of violating the Espionage Act, saying he would be at extreme risk of suicide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset, Michael D. Shear and Hailey Fuchs
title: On the eve of critical Georgia Senate runoffs, Trump complicates matters with more political pressure.
description: ATLANTA — The Georgia Senate runoffs will draw firepower from the highest levels of politics on Monday with visits by President Trump and President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., underscoring the urgency of an election to determine control of the Senate and held in the shadow of Mr. Trump’s persistent attacks on Republican state officials over his baseless claims of voter fraud.
content: ATLANTA — The Georgia Senate runoffs will draw firepower from the highest levels of politics on Monday with visits by President Trump and President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., underscoring the urgency of an election to determine control of the Senate and held in the shadow of Mr. Trump’s persistent attacks on Republican state officials over his baseless claims of voter fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Transcript: President Trump’s Phone Call With Georgia Election Officials
description: The president pressured Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger to overturn the results of the election in an hourlong phone conversation. Here is a transcript of the audio recording.
content: A leaked telephone conversation with President Trump, Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger of Georgia and others revealed that the president had urged the state’s top election official to overturn the results in his favor. The following is a transcript of the call, reported earlier by The Washington Post, which has been edited to remove the name of an election worker whom the president baselessly accused of fraud. (And here are highlights from the conversation.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Does Coconut Oil Deserve Its Health Halo?
description: “It’s been known for a long time that coconut oil raises blood levels of artery-damaging LDL cholesterol,” one expert said.
content: Coconut oil continues to be widely touted as a miracle food. Proponents, including a slew of celebrities, claim it promotes weight loss, lowers blood pressure and blood glucose, protects against heart disease, increases energy, reduces inflammation, erases wrinkles and even counters Alzheimer’s disease. Plus it tastes great, so what could be bad? And if you believe all that, I’ll offer to sell you the Brooklyn Bridge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Mr. Mayor’ and ‘Tiger’
description: Ted Danson plays a Los Angeles mayor in a new NBC sitcom. And HBO debuts the first part of a documentary about Tiger Woods.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Jan. 4-9. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Share Your College Essays
description: Class of 2024: It’s been a year like never before. How did you write about it?
content: The world just lived through one of the most wrenching and disruptive years in memory. For many young people applying to college, 2020 will be a year they will talk about and remember for the rest of their lives. A deeply formative year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Thailand, Japan and China impose new restrictions.
content: Thailand, which had been among the most successful countries in containing the coronavirus, imposed wide-ranging new restrictions on Monday as cases hit a daily high of 745. Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha urged people to stay home, and Bangkok ordered schools, bars and entertainment venues to close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: The Crossword Stumper
description: A look at one of the entries that fooled solvers in last week’s puzzles.
content: James Merritt IVES (1824-1895) was an American lithographer and co-founder of Currier & Ives, the prolific printmaking firm that advertised itself as “Publishers of Cheap and Popular Pictures.” The black and white prints were hand-colored and became records of the politics, history and manners of 19th-century America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: The pandemic has hit addiction recovery hard.
description: Addiction is often referred to as a disease of isolation, and overcoming that challenge has only become more difficult during a pandemic that has forced people indoors — in some cases to live lonely lives, with drugs and alcohol as a way to cope with the stress.
content: Addiction is often referred to as a disease of isolation, and overcoming that challenge has only become more difficult during a pandemic that has forced people indoors — in some cases to live lonely lives, with drugs and alcohol as a way to cope with the stress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal K. Katyal and Sam Koppelman
title: Why Congress Should Impeach Trump Again
description: And this time, he should be convicted. The country cannot risk his becoming president again.
content: The emergence of an audio recording of President Trump pressuring the Georgia secretary of state to overturn the results of the election is a harrowing moment in the history of our democracy. And though the number of his days in office is dwindling, the only appropriate response is to impeach Mr. Trump. Again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: What We Know About the Voting in Georgia So Far
description: Democrats may have claimed a bigger share of the early vote than they did in November’s election, election data shows. Some early votes may be counted more quickly on election night.
content: Georgia’s runoff elections on Tuesday are high-stakes contests that will determine which party controls the Senate and set the agenda for the new administration in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Trump, in Taped Call, Pressured Georgia Official to “Find” Votes to Overturn Election’
description: In this lesson, students will weigh whether President Trump crossed any legal or ethical lines during a phone call with Georgia’s secretary of state about the 2020 election results.
content: Featured Article: “Trump, in Taped Call, Pressured Georgia Official to ‘Find’ Votes to Overturn Election” by Michael D. Shear and Stephanie Saul
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
title: Chicago’s School Dispute Intensifies
description: Some teachers defied an order to begin in-person teaching
content: Some Chicago teachers are due back in school buildings today as the city begins its bitterly contested return to in-person teaching. But not every teacher is showing up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan Pablo Ramirez
title: Playing the ‘Green Lottery’: Life Inside Colombia’s Emerald Mines
description: For many of the men who hunt for the country’s prized gems, the mines are like casinos in the middle of the Andes: One stone could change it all.
content: I was half a mile into the mine shaft, and my heart was racing. Hunched underneath the low ceiling and hardly able to see, I was following along by listening to the splashes of the men’s steps in front of me. The water, dripping from above, was up to my ankles. Then we stopped. We’d come to a dead end, one of the miners said. In order for us to proceed, they needed to set off some dynamite.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jerome Powell’s future as chair of the Fed could be affected by its pandemic response.
description: Jerome H. Powell, the 67-year-old chair of the Federal Reserve, will face pressure from all sides in 2021, and he could find himself auditioning for his own job. His term expires in early 2022, which means that President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. will choose whether to renominate him.
content: Jerome H. Powell, the 67-year-old chair of the Federal Reserve, will face pressure from all sides in 2021, and he could find himself auditioning for his own job. His term expires in early 2022, which means that President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. will choose whether to renominate him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Phone Calls, Texts and Tinder — Georgia Campaigns Court Young Voters
description: As vast resources and hundreds of millions of dollars have been pumped into Georgia for the Senate runoffs, few groups have been as vigorously pursued as the state’s young voters.
content: ATLANTA — Invigorated by a surge in voter turnout in November that delivered a victory in Georgia for a Democratic presidential candidate for the first time in her life, and forced runoffs in two high-profile, high-stakes Senate races, Patricia Granda-Malaver got to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How Do You Feel About the Semester to Come?
description: The fall was a mess. How do you think spring will go?
content: Teachers and students, staff and parents: how do you think the spring of 2021 will go? What are you worried about? What are you hopeful for? What will look different, you think, in the months to come?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Trump Repeats Debunked Election Claims in Call With Georgia Official
description: The president recited a number of viral online falsehoods involving dead voters, Dominion voting machines, shredded ballots and a water leak, among other baseless claims of fraud.
content: President Trump, in an hourlong telephone call with Georgia’s Republican secretary of state, repeated a number of false and misleading claims about election results in the state that have been circulating on social media. Here’s a fact check.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Curtis Rush
title: On Video Calls, a Community Walks Through Hockey History
description: A weekly chat based in Toronto has provided a respite from isolation, connecting viewers with guests like Scotty Bowman.
content: TORONTO — The N.H.L. won’t start playing again until mid-January, but online hockey forums have been in midseason form for a while. And for some fans, the addition of video has made these chats an especially welcome diversion during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yusef Salaam, Kevin Richardson and Raymond Santana
title: We Are the ‘Exonerated 5.’ What Happened to Us Isn’t Past, It’s Present.
description: Deceptive interrogations and false confessions are all too common. New York can stop them.
content: On Dec. 19, 2002, a judge vacated our convictions for the brutal attack on Trisha Meili, who many know as the “Central Park jogger.” On that day, our 13-year fight for justice came to an end. The lies that we were told by detectives to wrongly convict us were finally exposed and ceased to hold power over us. Now, we are fighting to prevent others from facing the same fate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Nancy Pelosi Secures Another Term as Speaker, as Senate Hangs in Balance
description: The vote, largely along party lines, punctuated an opening day marked more by precaution than pomp, as the 117th Congress convened under the threat of a deadly pandemic.
content: WASHINGTON — Democrats returned Representative Nancy Pelosi of California to the House speakership on Sunday for what may be her final term, handing a tested leader control of the slimmest majority in almost two decades as Washington prepares for a new Democratic president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter and Karen Weise
title: Amazon, Berkshire and JPMorgan Will End Joint Health Care Venture
description: The company, Haven, had promised to disrupt the way large corporations deliver benefits to their employees.
content: A joint venture formed by Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase to explore new ways to deliver health care to their employees is disbanding, according to a short statement on its website. The company, Haven, will cease operations at the end of February — three years after its arrival sent shock waves through the health care industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu and Rebecca Robbins
title: As Rollout Falters, Scientists Debate New Vaccination Tactics
description: Should second doses be delayed? Should most adults receive half-doses? Scientists are pondering ways to get more shots into more arms.
content: As governments around the world rush to vaccinate their citizens against the surging coronavirus, scientists are locked in a heated debate over a surprising question: Is it wisest to hold back the second doses everyone will need, or to give as many people as possible an inoculation now — and push back the second doses until later?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Breznitz and David Adler
title: America Can’t Even Produce the Things It Invented
description: The United States can bring manufacturing back — which will bring back good jobs and protect national interests.
content: The panic in the United States over the lack of masks and ventilators for Covid-19 has mostly eased, but please, don’t let those scary few weeks fade too quickly. The scramble for medical equipment was a telling moment for the American economy because it revealed something alarming: The United States can no longer produce what it needs in a time of crisis, even if those things were invented here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: A New Year, Less Drama?
description: Not a chance! At least not yet. This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Welcome back! Believe me, we are more than ready to say goodbye to 2020 — right after we finish up this last bit of business down in Georgia. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne and Michael Gonchar
title: What Do You Hope for Most in 2021?
description: What do you wish for yourself, your loved ones, your community and the world?
content: We’re at the start of a new year; so far, though, it doesn’t seem all that much different than the last one.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Georgia Runoffs, Part 1: ‘We Are Black Diamonds’
description: Black voters will be integral to Democratic success in the upcoming Senate races. We speak to Stacey Abrams and LaTosha Brown, two Black women who are leading the charge in mobilizing the vote.
content: When Joe Biden won Georgia in November, one name kept cropping up again and again: Stacey Abrams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Tae McDermott
title: New Laws for Californians
description: Monday: A look at a few of the laws that went into effect on Jan. 1. Also: The pandemic surges in Los Angeles.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Tech Predictions for 2021
description: Times journalists share the technology-related developments they think will be big this year.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Adam Gase, Hired to Spark Jets’ Offense, Is Out After Two Seasons
description: Gase sputtered to a 9-23 record in a tenure during which star players left disgruntled and the franchise quarterback, Sam Darnold, went underdeveloped.
content: On the day the Jets introduced Adam Gase as their next head coach, their chief executive, Christopher Johnson, heralded an organizational shift. After hiring defensive-minded coaches for more than two decades, it was time for the Jets, Johnson said, to align with league trends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Cost of Fighting the Count
description: Awkward questions for the companies that donated to senators planning to challenge the 2020 election results.
content: Any remaining notions that the presidential transition would go smoothly were shattered this weekend when 11 Republican senators announced that they would not certify Joe Biden’s Electoral College victory during a joint Congressional session on Wednesday. At the same time, President Trump pressured Georgia’s secretary of state to “find” enough votes to flip the state to him, on a Saturday phone call that was recorded. (That said, the prospect of a constitutional crisis hasn’t rattled markets: U.S. futures are up this morning.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
title: Britain Re-enters Sweeping Lockdown as Virus Variant Rages
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson closed schools and declared a national lockdown in England, following on the heels of Scotland.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson imposed a strict new national lockdown on Monday as Britain’s desperate race to vaccinate its population risked being overtaken by a fast-spreading variant of the coronavirus that was on track to overwhelm the nation’s beleaguered hospitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: Slack Restores Service After Starting 2021 With Outage
description: The company apologized for the disruptions, which lasted for a few hours as users returned to work after the holidays.
content: Slack, the popular messaging platform used by millions of people worldwide, restored service after experiencing a major disruption on Monday as many employees in the United States returned to work after the holidays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: For an Exercise ‘Snack,’ Try the New Standing 7-Minute Workout
description: During pandemic lockdowns, many of us learned the importance of short home workouts. Take the 7-Day Well Challenge for a new exercise video and more ways to keep moving in 2021.
content: Make 2021 the year of the exercise snack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Iraq, Struggling to Pay Debts and Salaries, Plunges Into Economic Crisis
description: Oil-rich Iraq, its economy hobbled by neglect and corruption, has devalued its currency and had its imported electricity cut off for nonpayment.
content: BAGHDAD — In the wholesale market of Jamila, near Baghdad’s sprawling Sadr City neighborhood, a merchant, Hassan al-Mozani, was surrounded by towering piles of unsold 110-pound sacks of flour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Danforth, Chris Dodd, Chuck Hagel and Paul Kirk
title: When We Were Senators There Was Respect Across the Aisle. Let’s Get It Back.
description: Congress must regain the country’s trust. This is one way to start.
content: As veterans of decades of political campaigns and legislative battles, we, both Democrats and Republicans, share the question Americans have been asking for too long: What will it take to end the hyperpartisan polarization that has spurred so much hostility and distrust in the public square and has effectively paralyzed legislative action?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Republicans Begin New Congress Feuding Over Bid to Overturn Election
description: With President Trump ratcheting up his efforts to cling to power, the party has split over whether to back him, posing a major political test.
content: WASHINGTON — After four years of enabling and appeasing President Trump, Republicans find themselves at the end of his tenure in exactly the place they had so desperately tried to avoid: a toxic internecine brawl over his conduct and character that could badly damage their party.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: For Next Act, Idled Halftime Performers Try to Prepare and Cope
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 4, 2021.
content: “If you saw me practicing, you’d be like, ‘Oh, he’s only balancing on two chairs.’ But the intensity of six chairs is in my face.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor and Rick Rojas
title: ‘I wanted to scream.’ Georgia election official voices his exhaustion with Trump’s baseless fraud claims.
description: Gabriel Sterling, a top election official in Georgia, delivered a scathing refutation on Monday of President Trump’s false claims of voter fraud, running through a long list of already-debunked conspiracy theories and systematically debunking each one again.
content: Gabriel Sterling, a top election official in Georgia, delivered a scathing refutation on Monday of President Trump’s false claims of voter fraud, running through a long list of already-debunked conspiracy theories and systematically debunking each one again.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How ski resorts are bracing to survive the winter.
description: The ski industry already took a hit in the spring when the pandemic struck and many resorts had to close early, leading to $2 billion in losses and causing layoffs or furloughs of thousands of employees, according to the National Ski Areas Association, a trade group. The industry saw its lowest number of visits, 51 million, since the 2011 to 2012 season, the association said.
content: The ski industry already took a hit in the spring when the pandemic struck and many resorts had to close early, leading to $2 billion in losses and causing layoffs or furloughs of thousands of employees, according to the National Ski Areas Association, a trade group. The industry saw its lowest number of visits, 51 million, since the 2011 to 2012 season, the association said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs and Chris Cameron
title: Highlights of Trump’s Call With the Georgia Secretary of State
description: The president pressed the secretary, Brad Raffensperger, to “find” enough ballots for him to overturn the election.
content: In a leaked telephone conversation, President Trump pressured Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger of Georgia, a fellow Republican, on Saturday to overturn the election results in his state, reciting debunked claims of election fraud. Here are some notable excerpts from the recording, which was obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: In a Topsy-Turvy Pandemic World, China Offers Its Version of Freedom
description: Surveillance and censorship bolster Beijing’s uncompromising grip on power. But in the country’s cities and streets, people have resumed normal lives.
content: Duncan Clark’s flight was rolling down the runway in Paris in late October when President Emmanuel Macron announced a second national lockdown in France. The country had nearly 50,000 new Covid-19 infections that day. The United States had almost 100,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Supreme Leader of Voter Suppression
description: Trump is bolstering anti-patriotism in the digital age.
content: Regardless of what has happened since the election two months ago, or what may happen in the next few weeks, Joe Biden will almost assuredly be inaugurated the president on Jan. 20, and Donald J. Trump’s official reign of presidential terror will end that day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: An Insurgency From Inside the Oval Office
description: President Trump’s effort to overturn the election he lost has gone beyond mere venting of grievances at the risk of damaging the very American democracy he is charged with defending.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s relentless effort to overturn the result of the election that he lost has become the most serious stress test of American democracy in generations, one led not by outside revolutionaries intent on bringing down the system but by the very leader charged with defending it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: What We Learned From Week 17 of the N.F.L. Season
description: Green Bay secured home-field advantage, Buffalo ended Miami’s season and Cleveland ended its 17-season playoff drought.
content: The Green Bay Packers secured the top seed in the N.F.C. playoffs, while making an excellent argument for Aaron Rodgers as the N.F.L.’s most valuable player. The Buffalo Bills got the No. 2 seed in the A.F.C., while effectively ending the Miami Dolphins’ season. And the Cleveland Browns, after 17 seasons that ended in frustration, are back in the playoffs. It was an exciting Sunday even by Week 17 standards, and the playoff field is now set.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Shaw
title: Plans to Raze Louis Kahn-Designed Dorms in India Are on Hold
description: After an outcry from preservationists and architects, the Indian Institute of Management in Ahmedabad said that it would reconvene to consider the dorms’ future.
content: Plans to raze 14 of 18 dormitories designed by the architect Louis Kahn for the Indian Institute of Management in Ahmedabad that set off an international outcry were rolled back on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Obama suggests Trump is threatening the ‘fundamental principles of our democracy’ ahead of Senate runoffs in Georgia.
description: Former president Barack Obama cast Tuesday’s runoff elections in Georgia as an existential struggle for core democratic institutions, hours after a recording was made public of President Trump pressuring an official of the state to “find” enough votes to overturn his loss there.
content: Former president Barack Obama cast Tuesday’s runoff elections in Georgia as an existential struggle for core democratic institutions, hours after a recording was made public of President Trump pressuring an official of the state to “find” enough votes to overturn his loss there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Farber
title: Gerry Marsden, a Hitmaker With the Pacemakers, Dies at 78
description: For a time in the early ’60s, with songs like“Ferry Cross the Mersey,” “Don’t Let the Sun Catch You Crying” and “You’ll Never Walk Alone,” the Pacemakers rivaled the Beatles.
content: Gerry Marsden, whose band Gerry and the Pacemakers proved to be formidable rivals to the Beatles in the early Liverpool rock scene of the 1960s, scoring smash hits like “Ferry Cross the Mersey,” “Don’t Let the Sun Catch You Crying” and “You’ll Never Walk Alone,” died on Sunday in the Liverpool area. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: $900 Billion Won’t Carry Biden Very Far
description: Despite new pandemic aid, he confronts an economic crisis unlike any since he last entered office in 2009. And political headwinds have only stiffened.
content: With his presidential inauguration just weeks away, Joseph R. Biden Jr. is confronting an economic crisis that is utterly unparalleled and yet eerily familiar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Schram
title: Top Prospects Take an Unconventional Path to the World Juniors
description: The ice hockey tournament has featured the first N.C.A.A. players on Team Russia, a Canadian who went to an unheralded prep school and four Californians who benefited from a 1990s hockey boom.
content: Each holiday season, the World Junior Championship offers hockey fans a preview of the next wave of young stars heading to the N.H.L. Over the last decade, the tournament’s most valuable players have included the Rangers’ first overall pick Alexis Lafreniere (2020), Filip Forsberg of the Nashville Predators (2014) and John Gibson of the Anaheim Ducks (2013).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: ‘Relapsing Left and Right’: Trying to Overcome Addiction in a Pandemic
description: Substance-abuse centers are shutting and relying on virtual programming, just as more and more people turn to drugs and alcohol.
content: Jackie Ré, who runs a substance-use disorder facility in New Jersey, gathered the 12 female residents of her center in the living room on March 27 and told them that the coronavirus outbreak had forced the center to limit contact with the outside world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: In Reversal, Pentagon Announces Aircraft Carrier Nimitz Will Remain in Middle East
description: The acting defense secretary abruptly reversed his previous order to redeploy the Nimitz, which he had done over the objections of his top military advisers.
content: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon said on Sunday that it had ordered the aircraft carrier Nimitz to remain in the Middle East because of Iranian threats against President Trump and other American officials, just three days after sending the warship home as a signal to de-escalate rising tensions with Tehran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Vaccine Rolls Out Slowly as Virus Surges
description: So far, most vaccinations have been given on weekdays, and the sense of urgency that New Yorkers expected has not yet emerged.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Parul Koul and Chewy Shaw
title: We Built Google. This Is Not the Company We Want to Work For.
description: Our company’s motto used to be “Don’t be evil.” An organized work force will help us live up to it.
content: On Nov. 1, 2018, at 11:10 a.m., some 20,000 Google employees, along with employees of Waymo, Verily and other Alphabet companies, stopped working and walked off the job in cities around the world. A week earlier, The New York Times reported that the company had paid tens of millions of dollars to two executives who had been accused of sexual misconduct toward our co-workers, staying silent about the alleged abuse and letting them walk away with no consequences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri and Matthew Sedacca
title: Driver Kills Boy, 4, and Injures 2nd Child Outside Yeshiva, Police Say
description: The van driver had just dropped off the children, the police said. The fatality came as reckless driving has increased during the pandemic.
content: A man driving a van fatally struck a 4-year-old boy and critically injured a 6-year-old boy moments after he had dropped them off at a yeshiva in Brooklyn on Monday morning, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse and Glenn Thrush
title: Cotton will oppose Trump’s effort to challenge Biden’s win as Republicans splinter ahead of Georgia runoff.
description: After four years of enabling and appeasing President Trump, Republicans find themselves at the end of his tenure in exactly the place they had so desperately tried to avoid: a toxic internecine brawl over his conduct and character that could badly damage their party.
content: After four years of enabling and appeasing President Trump, Republicans find themselves at the end of his tenure in exactly the place they had so desperately tried to avoid: a toxic internecine brawl over his conduct and character that could badly damage their party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Indiana to Host Entire 2021 N.C.A.A. Men’s Basketball Tournament
description: The 67-game hoops bonanza will be played in and around Indianapolis as the N.C.A.A. tries to limit travel during the pandemic.
content: The N.C.A.A., in an attempt to limit the threat of coronavirus among teams, announced an agreement Monday to hold its signature men’s basketball tournament entirely in Indiana in March and early April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund Lee
title: Quibi Is Dead, but Roku TV May Resurrect Its Content
description: The failed streaming company led by Jeffrey Katzenberg and Meg Whitman is in talks with Roku about a deal.
content: Quibi was the biggest bust of the streaming boom. But it has something Roku wants — more than 100 original programs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Cuttlefish Took Something Like a Marshmallow Test. Many Passed.’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about a new cuttlefish discovery and then design their own science experiments.
content: Featured Article: “Cuttlefish Took Something Like a Marshmallow Test. Many Passed.” by Veronique Greenwood
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: The N.B.A.’s halftime performers feel the strain of the pandemic.
description: Steve Max usually spends his winters telling big crowds at basketball arenas to put their hands up and to touch their shoulders and to cover their eyes. He travels the country entertaining fans at halftime.
content: Steve Max usually spends his winters telling big crowds at basketball arenas to put their hands up and to touch their shoulders and to cover their eyes. He travels the country entertaining fans at halftime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Barkan
title: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Knows How to Fix Housing
description: The first step to addressing the country’s housing affordability problem is to repeal the Faircloth Amendment.
content: Joe Biden will enter office facing a humanitarian catastrophe unlike any in modern times. Covid-19 is still ravaging the country and the economic fallout remains severe: On top of the lost jobs and closed businesses, an eviction crisis is looming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Bobby Shmurda Eligible for Release From Prison in February
description: The Brooklyn rapper, whose viral ascent was cut short by gang conspiracy charges, may serve the remainder of his seven-year sentence on parole, thanks to good behavior.
content: The Brooklyn rapper Bobby Shmurda, whose quick rise in the music industry was cut short when he was arrested on gang conspiracy charges in 2014, will be eligible for release from prison next month, the New York State Department of Corrections said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What’s Next in Your Netflix Queue?
description: Bela Bajaria decides.
content: Bela Bajaria has an unprecedented job at Netflix. In an executive shake-up this year, she was elevated from head of “local language” (read: non-English) productions to a newly created role, head of global television (read: all TV, everywhere). Her promotion signals how much Netflix is banking on international markets and diverse content to help it win the streaming wars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Fiat Chrysler and Peugeot Approve a Merger They Need to Survive
description: Shareholders of the two companies voted to join forces in an effort to cope with a major technology shift and plummeting sales.
content: Shareholders of Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and PSA, the French maker of Peugeot, Citroën and Opel cars, voted on Monday to merge in an effort to acquire the scale necessary to survive in an industry gripped by technological change and pummeled by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis and Ivan Penn
title: Home Solar Is Growing, but Big Installers Are Still Losing Money
description: Some companies are having trouble surviving and making money installing panels because of intense competition and the high costs of doing business.
content: The home solar business is growing fast as thousands of homeowners install panels on their roofs to save money. Yet the biggest companies that install and finance home solar systems are reporting hundreds of millions of dollars in losses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: A Timeout for the N.B.A.’s Halftime Performers Is Costing Them Big
description: The pandemic has all but shut down the income streams for halftime performers, who typically make $1,500 to $5,000 a show. The emotional toll is high as well.
content: Steve Max usually spends his winters telling big crowds at basketball arenas to put their hands up and to touch their shoulders and to cover their eyes. Max is a professional Simon Says caller who travels the country entertaining fans at halftime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: China Moves to Punish Lawyers Hired to Help Hong Kong Activists
description: Lu Siwei and Ren Quanniu were barred from aiding a group of pro-democracy protesters who were arrested at sea, but could still lose their licenses.
content: HONG KONG — The Chinese legal authorities have threatened to revoke the licenses of two lawyers hired to help a group of Hong Kong protesters who were arrested last year while trying to flee to Taiwan by speedboat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Trump’s Call Leaves Allies Fearful for American Democracy
description: Many now take the president’s disregard for democratic and ethical norms for granted, but also fear its effect on America’s standing in the world.
content: BRUSSELS — President Trump’s extraordinary, wheedling telephone call to state officials in Georgia seeking to overturn the election results there has shaken many Europeans — not so much for what it reveals about Mr. Trump himself, but for what it may portend for the health of American democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan and Kay Nolan
title: Pharmacist Accused of Tampering With Vaccine Was Conspiracy Theorist, Police Say
description: The police say a Wisconsin pharmacist believed the Moderna vaccine would harm people and tried to sabotage the effort to vaccinate frontline workers.
content: A pharmacist who was arrested on charges that he intentionally sabotaged more than 500 doses of the Covid-19 vaccine at a Wisconsin hospital was “an admitted conspiracy theorist” who believed the vaccine could harm people and “change their DNA,” according to the police in Grafton, Wis., where the man was employed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Is It Too Late to Impeach Trump Again?
description: The president showed this weekend that he still has Georgia on his mind.
content: Bret Stephens: Belated happy new year, Gail. I was hoping we could celebrate the arrival of 2021 by never mentioning Donald Trump’s name again, except maybe as a punchline to jokes involving foul-mouthed parrots. But then our friends at The Washington Post broke the news that the president begged and bullied Brad Raffensperger, Georgia’s secretary of state, to “find” him the “11,780 votes” he needed to flip the state’s 16 electoral votes his way. To his credit, Raffensperger told him to get lost (proof, by the way, that not every Republican official has lost his soul).
source.name: The New York Times

title: Listen to Excerpts From President Trump’s Call With Georgia Officials
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About South Africa?
description: Can you find South Africa on a map? What else do you know about this African nation with about 59 million people?
content: Can you find South Africa on a map? What else do you know about this African nation with about 59 million people?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Quealy and Alicia Parlapiano
title: Election Day Voting in 2020 Took Longer in America’s Poorest Neighborhoods
description: An analysis of voting times based on anonymous smartphone location data.
content: An analysis of voting times based on anonymous smartphone location data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Corum and Carl Zimmer
title: How Bharat Biotech’s Vaccine Works
description: Using inactivated coronaviruses to train the immune system.
content: Using inactivated coronaviruses to train the immune system.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $2.6 Million in California
description: A modernist hillside retreat in Topanga, a French country-style home in Santa Barbara and a renovated 1929 house in Pacific Grove.
content: A modernist hillside retreat in Topanga, a French country-style home in Santa Barbara and a renovated 1929 house in Pacific Grove.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: It’s Back to Lockdown for Britain as Cases Soar
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson addressing Britons on Monday.
content: Prime Minister Boris Johnson addressing Britons on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Scotland Will Go Into Lockdown After Coronavirus Variant Spread
description: Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland’s first minister, announced on Monday that the country will go back into lockdown until the end of January due to the increase of coronavirus cases from a newly discovered variant.
content: Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland’s first minister, announced on Monday that the country will go back into lockdown until the end of January due to the increase of coronavirus cases from a newly discovered variant.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Listen to Excerpts From the President’s Call
description: President Trump pressured Georgia’s secretary of state, Brad Raffensperger, to overturn the state’s election results.
content: President Trump pressured Georgia’s secretary of state, Brad Raffensperger, to overturn the state’s election results.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 4, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 4, 2021.
content: An article on Saturday, about New York’s moratorium on evictions, incorrectly reported that the wife of Diba Gaye, a 65-year-old immigrant facing eviction, had died of Covid-19 in April, based on information that Mr. Gaye provided to The Times and to his lawyer. After the article was published, Mr. Gaye acknowledged to The Times and to his lawyer that his wife had died of heart disease, and had not contracted the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Wants to ‘Find’ Votes in Georgia
description: Readers decry the president’s phone call to Georgia’s secretary of state and efforts in Congress to overturn the Electoral College vote.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Evoking the Grandeur of the Penn Station of Yore
description: Readers applaud the opening of the Moynihan Train Hall. Also: Flavored Oreos.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
